children.value:
Washington, D.C. is the capital of the United States. Located between Maryland and Virginia, this land area of 61.05 miles is a federal district and thus not under the jurisdiction of a state. The population of the district is 672,228 as of July 2015, and has grown over 11% since 2010.1 (See Exhibit 1.) This is likely due to the economy of the city and the growing culture within the area. Professional, business, health and education services make up 60% of the D.C. economy, with a declining unemployment rate at 6.1% and 60,500 jobs added to the market in just the last year.2 53% of the labor force holds a bachelor’s degree, with an average per capita income of $46,500.1 Home of the federal government, Washington D.C. also attracts a lot of tourism and federal jobs which help in boosting the local economy. National monuments, museums, entertainment venues, and lots of green space help in making this capital one many enjoy. However, what other interesting aspects to the city are there?
The poverty line in D.C. is 17.3%, a 3 percent higher rate than the national average. There is a racial minority majority, with the largest race group being African Americans, totaling 48.3% of the population.1 (See Exhibit 2.) These factors lead to one of the city’s main urban planning issues: the inclusivity of race, income, and age groups.3 Furthermore, the district and its unique identity introduces several other planning issues needing to be addressed.

padding-bottom: 37.81190019193858%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/jpeg;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;

children.value:
The thesis for D.C.’s urban plan is to foster a community of inclusivity where a person can choose where to live, work, learn, or travel freely and independent of their race, income, or age.3 The district is focusing on five main problems in their planning to achieve this: managing growth, creating successful neighborhoods, increasing education and employment access, connecting the whole city, and building a green and healthy community.4 To succeed in these ideas, they have updated their zoning regulations,5 are in the process of creating more transit-oriented development,6 and are introducing more large-area planning with an emphasis on creating affordable housing.5
Washington D.C. is growing at an alarming rate, faster than the 2006 comprehensive plan intended for. (See Exhibit 1.) Thus a major aspect of D.C.’s future community planning is how to best account for this population change. This huge growth rate in the population is a double-edged sword from an urban planning perspective. On one hand, this growth can cause housing projects and businesses to expand outside of the concentrated central and northwest D.C wealthy areas and spread across the city. This growing population can also increase the urban density, which could eliminate the need for cars and thus reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the area.7
However, this population growth also has caused housing prices to skyrocket over the past ten years. This rise in housing costs has been accompanied by salaries remaining largely the same, and new building projects are not featuring affordable housing.8 This has caused D.C.’s poverty rate to be growing while other cities are experiencing declining poverty rates such as New Orleans and Salt Lake City.9 Affordable housing has become a paramount issue due to this heavy growth.

Transit has also been heavily affected recently by population changes in the district. The metro has been shut down for the majority of 2016 for repairs, and it simply is not feasible anymore for the metro to be the main transit system for D.C. unless it expands (especially on the green and yellow lines) and receives a greater budget.10 There’s too many people on the metro lines during rush hour, there’s too many cars on the streets, and the city is attempting to find a way to fix these issues.11 The city is currently experimenting with streetcar and bike transit systems.6 Without good transit options it becomes difficult for the city to be interconnected.
This population growth has also brought up urban density questions for the city. In D.C. there are fewer families and more single-resident households than in the past, with the average resident-per-household in the city at 2.22 people.1 Where will this new population live in the city when building development is so heavily regulated?
Furthermore, D.C. recognizes the huge issue of global warming and how urban planning can both adapt and mitigate this damage to the environment. The capital is looking into ways to be more sustainable while still having a high-functioning city. Planners have to face the issues of more severe storms, raising in sea levels, and possible compromises to the city’s infrastructure.12 By facing these challenges they are adapting to climate change. However, D.C. is also looking to make strides in mitigating climate change, but planners have to find the most effective way for the rest of the city to adopt these green policies.

children.value: With all these problems for planners, there are a lot of setbacks as well. Crime is a huge issue, with 64 annual crimes per 1,000 residents.1 D.C. residents are fearful of the crime in their city (See Exhibit 3.), and planners need to find ways to address this or else families and others will be driven out of the city. Crime has effects on the safety of districts, and has direct effects to multiple other factors of the city such as economy, housing costs, and population growth.9

The diversity in population with blacks making up 48% of the population and whites at 35% of the population brings issues as well: these ethnic groups often are in separate areas of the city, and the issue needing to be addressed is how to make the city more inclusive of all incomes and races. (See Exhibit 2.) This segregation of races in different areas of the city makes it difficult to create a more interconnected city.1
The Historic Landmark and Historic District Protection Act of 1978 instituted a Historic preservation program which stated preservation of historic landmarks is beneficial to the community as a whole. There are 40 historic districts in Washington D.C. which must be preserved. This also creates a unique setback for D.C. planners. This preservation makes it difficult to set forth plans for the future in those districts, as there are many regulations that make it difficult to bring new development to the districts. Planners have to figure out ways in which to make historic areas more sustainable, more dense, and more affordable while also being limited in what they are able to change about these districts.13

D.C. also has a lot of commuters that come from outside of the district to work. (See Exhibit 4.) This creates a reliance on car transportation in the district as often people traveling from these areas are traveling by car. A possible solution to this setback would be the extension of the metro with a better revenue model so commuters would not have to rely on a car to get to work.6

width:100%;height:100%;margin:0;vertical-align:middle;position:absolute;top:0;left:0;box-shadow:inset 0px 0px 0px 400px white;

children.value: Washington D.C. uses a comprehensive plan to give guidelines for the urban planning of the city. Published in 2006, the D.C. plan’s central thesis is to foster an inclusive city as previously explained.3 City planning is structured through 10 area elements that make up the entire city, with each element focusing on the unique character of that area.14 The plan, though going into specifics about certain neighborhoods, largely remains general and is meant to serve as an overview for all planning in the city for the foreseeable future. Chapter 25 of this plan goes into depth about the implementation of the comprehensive plan. One main implementation strategy is holding small-area planning committees across the district to make assure that progress is on track. Planners also realized that the comprehensive plan had to be a long-range plan if it were to ever be fully administered. Accounting for the future is one of the the central ways in which D.C. hopes to maintain the implementation of its comprehensive plan.15 The District government also gives an annual capital improvements budget, and the comprehensive plan seeks to have its major issues featured within that budget so implementation can be maintained.4 Furthermore, the comprehensive plan is intended to be updated every four years, with a major revision every 12 years to make sure long-term planning is proceeding as intended. In addition to the comprehensive plan, D.C. also features small area plans, a historic preservation plan, and center city plans.3

One of the central characteristics of Washington D.C. is a development regulation. The Height of Buildings Act of 1910 established that a building’s maximum height within D.C. would be the width of the adjacent street plus 20 feet. This limit capped out at 130 feet. This development regulation has given D.C. a unique look compared to other cities in the country.16 The height limit has created an open feel to the city, a refreshing alternative to the feeling of being cloistered off by tall buildings alongside narrow avenues experienced in other major U.S. cities. This regulation further enhances the historic feel to the city, and helps prevent an urban heat island effect. However, this regulation also makes it harder for the city to increase its density as it becomes impossible to build upwards. This is why cohousing and other efforts are so necessary with the current residents per household coming in at a low 2.22 persons.1

D.C. approved a new zoning code on January 14th of this year. These new development regulations were received fondly by the district’s population. It will now be legal for accessory units in areas where it wasn’t before. This may increase the amount of granny pods within the city and help with aging in place. New building development, especially those near alternative transportation options, will be allowed less space for parking which should bolster alternative transportation modes as well as the availability for lower cost housing. Corner grocery stores in residential areas have now been allowed as well, which should help lower food insecurity in the city. The zoning of the downtown area has also been expanded to encompass the riverfront and other high density areas nearby.5 The zoning regulations feature a good amount of high density commercial land use in the downtown area with a fair amount of mixed use high-density residential and commercial areas. Inclusionary zoning is not apparent throughout the whole district however, with much of the commercial and residential areas being separate zones.17
Historic preservation is also an important aspect of the city that calls for development regulation.13 This preservation previously described is a setback to future development, but it also preserves the unique integrity of the city and its huge historical importance. These historical landmarks benefit all as they foster a sense of place and community.

children.value: The Comprehensive plan made huge strides in the district in multiple sectors. 5,000 new building units were created, alongside 2,000 units being rehabilitated that were labelled in the comprehensive plan. 20,000 more jobs have been created, and there has been an 11% increase in the enrollment to public schools. Amount of bike commuters doubled over the course of ten years, and 3% more households do not own a car in the city anymore.

Sustainability has also greatly increased since the induction of the comprehensive plan, with double the amount of green roof space and the creation of the Sustainable DC Initiative which sets forth a plan to make DC the greenest city in the country by 2032. Even more impressive is that in 2012, 22.4 million square feet of construction in D.C. received LEED certification. In the district, sharing programs are greatly increasing in numbers as well. There is a Capital Bikeshare program alongside 1,000 vehicles for car-sharing.4

However, the plan still has some issues to iron out alongside these effective steps forward. They need to find better ways to expand infrastructure and direct the growth of the city. The best way to achieve this is more transit-oriented development so there is less needed space for parking garages and streets.
With the recent baby boom, they need to find a way to retain families by improving safety in neighborhoods and quality of public education even further. (See Exhibits 5 & 6.) This should be achieved by increasing budgets to elementary and high school level education, and assuring that these schools provide equal educational opportunity across the entire city. This concentration on early educational opportunity should help in lowering the crime and poverty rate if future generations are given the means to do so.

One of the biggest failures of the comprehensive plan is not creating affordable housing to the level that is needed. Housing prices are rising, with 72,000 applications for public housing.18 The district has had an issue supporting its impoverished and lower class, (See Exhibit 7.) and need to find an alternative to the high cost housing. The best way to achieve this would be by improving urban density. This can be done by more cohousing projects, and increasing the zoning density regulations outside of downtown as currently it is mostly low to medium density residential areas. The comprehensive plan has been very successful in what it set out to do, but there are still a few hiccups.

children.value: Washington D.C. is one of the leading cities in the country for sustainability. In 2013, the district published the Sustainable DC plan. Over a nine year period the DC government went from 100% fossil fuel usage to 100% renewable energy. (See Exhibit 8.) In 2007, the DC Green Building Act was established that set forth building standards and incentives for green construction. This act reduces 30% energy usage in existing building codes, and also formed regulations to assure low impact development.4

What makes D.C. truly enjoyable for me is the ample access to nature. Whenever I visit other cities the domination of concrete and buildings is suffocating. D.C. has the National Mall, the waterfront, and a good amount of parks and trees so I always can feel connected to nature but still have access to the amenities a city provides. D.C. is ranked 6th in the country for cities with the most park accessibility, with 96% of residents being within a 10 minute walk to a park. Nearly 20% of the district is parkland.19 I think this is critical to the success of the city. The park spaces create a community space where people can freely interact. Furthermore, with the recent baby boom these parks will become paramount to the success of raising a child in a healthy way so that they may be freerange kids and not suffer from nature-deficit disorder.

D.C.’s devotion to sustainability is my favorite aspect of the city. Trees are constantly being planted along the streets, and there is a goal to achieve a 40% tree canopy by 2033. A climate action plan has also been created that seeks to reduce greenhouse gas emission by 50% over the next twenty years. Efforts are being placed into transit-oriented development, with higher housing densities near metro stations, and non-auto transit modes such as bike sharing. Another big issue the district is tackling is food insecurity in the area. More than 425,000 grocery stores were created between 2009 and 2014, raising the percentage of citizens within walking distance to a grocery store by almost 20%.4

However, D.C. still has some work to do. Though I believe the district will only better their sustainability over the coming years, there are still some aspects of their plan that is lacking. There should be more efforts to be more sustainable with housing. More cohousing options should be available, and there should be inclusionary zoning laws. Cohousing would be able to create more dense communities while still maintaining the building height regulations. Inclusionary zoning would allow more housing opportunity to the lower income of the community and help intermingle the different economic groups of the city. Transit options are constantly improving such as the introduction of the streetcar in 2013, but the metro needs a revamp with better pricing and new revenue models if it hopes to retain users.6 Overall, the city is on the right track to sustainability, but needs extra pushing by the public for more transit-oriented development alongside more affordable housing.

children.value: The city has come a long way since it was planned in 1791. The city is historic, but also leads by example in its plans for the future. D.C. is becoming one of the greenest cities in the country, alongside a thriving economy and being a cultural hub. However, it still needs to iron out some issues in regard to affordable housing, better transit options, and decreasing the poverty rate. It’s development regulations is one of its strong suits, as it keeps a unity in design across the district. Furthermore, the comprehensive plan for the city has induced significant, positive changes across the district since it was established in 2006. The city has continuously proven that it is committed to urban planning, as seen by the consistent updating of the plan and its zoning ordinances. It is a great city, and will only become greater if this focus on sustainable urban planning continues.
